Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Harnessing Smart Grid Data to Enable Resilient and Efficient Electricity

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to harness Smart Grid data (Big Data) to enable more resilient and efficient electricity. Three research sub-projects contribute to this goal. Project 1 combines a new ?Random Chemistry? computational algorithm with complex networks methods to find patterns of vulnerability in power systems, and uses the results to reduce cascading failure blackout risk. Project 2 transforms smart grid data into actionable information about the health of a power grid by looking at statistical properties (structured noise) in data from grid sensors. Projects 1 and 2 seeks to make power grids more resilient to fluctuations from renewable generation or weather events. Project 3 uses crowdsourcing to identify trends affecting residential energy consumption through a web-based energy efficiency social network.

Intellectual Merit
This project integrates research ideas from diverse scientific disciplines, including complex systems, graph theory, data science, computational intelligence and crowdsourcing. Projects 1 and 2 use abstract complex systems approaches, while retaining critical information about the physics of power systems. By using data from real power systems the project will contribute to the emerging field of data science. The third project combines computational intelligence with crowdsourcing in a way that could open new ways to improve energy efficiency.

Broader Impacts
This project tests new educational approaches, including a unique LEGO-based grid simulator, and integrates smart grid data into new courses. New curriculum and a hands on ?smart grid road show? will be leveraged to attract students from diverse educational and demographic backgrounds to study electric energy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this CAREER project was to harness Smart Grid data to enable resilient and efficient electricity. This broad goal was divided into three subprojects:

  1. Transforming large amounts of data from power system simulations into actionable information about the risk of cascading blackouts.
  2. Identifying early warning signs of blackout risk in time-series data from sensors in power transmission networks and then use this information to mitigate risk.
  3. Combine real-world data from smart meters with crowdsourced data to help people to better understand the energy consumption in their home.

All three subprojects led to important innovations that are having a significant impact on the field of power systems engineering and providing connections between power systems and other disciplines.

The first subproject led to the invention of a new method for cascading failure analysis, known as the ?influence graph.? In this method we run many cascading failure simulations and then use the data from those simulations to build a graph representation of the interdependencies among the transmission lines in a power network. The resulting system can find a small number of critical transmission lines (e.g., 5-10) that could be improved leading to an 80% reduction in blackout risk. Furthermore, the influence graph method provides a useful bridge link between the emerging science of complex networks and electric power systems. The resulting research paper has been cited over 80 times by both power systems and network science researchers.  

The second subproject led to the discovery of statistical techniques that can identify early warning signs of blackout risk in data from new sensors that are being rapidly adopted in power transmission networks (synchronized phasor measurement units). The results show that under some conditions variance and autocorrelation in voltage and current measurements increase before voltage collapse occurs. This insight led to the invention of a new control system that uses statistical data to make better decisions about how one can manage power system components. Furthermore, this research linked together ongoing innovations in the field of power systems with emerging research into statistical early warning signs in the ecology and statistical physics literature.

The third subproject led to the development of a new method for crowdsourcing the discovery of factors that can led to particular outcomes of interest, such as the energy consumption of a home. The project resulted in a new energy efficiency social network, known as ?energyminder? in which individuals could ask one another questions and machine learning tools identified patterns that help people better understand why their homes use more or less energy than average. The project made use of data from ?Smart Meters? (advanced metering infrastructure) deployed through US investments in Grid Modernization during 2009-2012.

In addition to these research discoveries, the project contributed to the education of 4 Ph.D. students, one of whom is now working as a professor in Oregon and two of whom are working in innovative industry positions. In addition, the project supported several MS and undergraduate students, who are now working in the energy industry or pursuing Ph.D. degrees at other universities (e.g., MIT and Cal Tech). Several of these students are women or come from groups underrepresented in science and technology careers. 

Furthermore, this project contributed to electricity industry collaborations that continue to spur innovation. For example, the project supported collaborations with Burlington Electric and Green Mountain Power related to the growth of advanced metering infrastructure. That collaboration led, in part, to the launch of a startup company, Packetized Energy, of which the PI is CEO and co-founder and which is developing next generation Internet of Things technology to manage distributed energy resources in electric power systems. The project also supported a collaboration with Vermont?s transmission utility (VELCO), which led to a new project in which VELCO and the University of Vermont are working to develop a new software platform through which VELCO is studying the transmission system reliability changes that emerge as variable wind and solar generation grow rapidly in the US Northeast.

This project also led to the development of a number of important and innovative educational outcomes. The project supported the development of a new course in ?Smart Grid? technology and policy, now known as ?EE 217: Smart Grid?. This interdisciplinary course introduced a broad range of students from engineering, computer science and natural resources, to the rapid technology changes that are occurring in the electricity industry. Key elements from this curriculum are publicly available on the PI?s web site. In addition, the project supported the PI?s involvement in an innovative program known as the Vermont Governor?s Institute, a summer program for high school students who want to pursue knowledge in science and technology. Finally, the project supported the development of a new educational tool, known as MechGrid, which uses LEGO components to illustrate important power systems concepts.
